questionTask.text: What are some recommended resources for preparing for a PM interview, and how should one use them effectively?
What are some key skills and qualities that PM interviewers look for in candidates, and how can one demonstrate them during the interview?
How can one approach strategy-type questions in a PM interview, and what are some common frameworks or techniques for addressing them?

statementsTask.text:
To prepare for a PM interview, there are several recommended resources. One should start by understanding and remembering key knowledge required to perform well in a PM interview (source 0). It is also helpful to read articles related to the company you are interviewing for and take notes (source 7). Additionally, one should finalize all frameworks for PM design, strategy, analytical, and technical interviews and practice 1-2 questions in detail per day (source 8). Mock interviews with calibrated PMs are also recommended (source 2), and peer-interviews can be useful to see different approaches people take (source 3). Sample PM questions can be found online (source 4), but it is important to note that a good PM will always think about drawbacks and loopholes without prompting from interviewers (source 5). Finally, while The Design of Everyday Things was recommended by multiple PMs, it is not something that would be too useful for PM interviews (source 9). To use these resources effectively, one should take notes, practice consistently, and seek feedback from others.

Sources:
[0] : understand and remember key knowledge required to perform well in a PM interview
[1] Note: I suggest doing mock interviews with calibrated PMs (those who have done interviews before and know how to evaluate candidates).
[2] Peer-interviews can be useful too so you can see different approaches people take; and they are often better when you are not confident yet to practice with PMs.
[3] You can find a lot of sample PM questions (but not necessarily answers) from:
[4] A good PMs will always think about these drawbacks / loopholes without prompting from interviewers.
[5] Write down notes as you read good articles related to the company you are interviewing for!
[6] Goal: finalize all frameworks for PM design, strategy, analytical, and technical interviews; Practice in details 1-2 questions / day and schedule for mock interviews in phase 3.

To prepare for a PM interview, it is recommended to read "Cracking the PM Interview" and "Decode and Conquer" [1] [2] [3] [4]. Additionally, the Stratechery blog is a great resource for tech trends and strategy [5]. For strategy type questions, it is useful to consider the company's goals, market opportunity, and success metrics [6] [7] [8]. It is also important to have knowledge of data structures such as arrays, linked lists, trees, graphs, hash tables, stacks, and queues [9], as well as database designs and web vulnerabilities [10] [11]. For product design, steps to designing product features, user segmentation/persona, and customer research methodology are important [12] [13] [14]. Analytical skills are also important, including knowledge of metrics and data collection, as well as how to analyze issues and trends [15] [16]. It is also important to have a framework for reviewing and finalizing strategies, such as tradeoffs, new market entry, CEO-level issues and strategy, and pricing [17]. To build a framework, it is recommended to start with simplified frameworks and modify and add notes as you practice [18]. It is also important to clarify the market, timing, and constraints, and to assume goals and why they matter for the company [19] [20]. Additionally, it is useful to consider the value chain and competitors to decide where to play [21]. Paying attention to user trends and current events is also a plus [22]. To prepare, it is recommended to practice 70-100 questions on your own, 2-3 times each, and to do mock interviews with calibrated PMs [23] [24] [25]. It is also important to be confident, user-centric, and always evaluate your ideas and strategies [26] [27] [28]. Finally, having good moonshot ideas that are not obvious and blend new technology is a plus [29] [30].

Sources:
[1] Note: Before the start of phase 1, please read through 2 books (1) Cracking the PM interview (2) Decode and conquer book.
[2] Cracking the PM interview - reference only.
[3] Decode and conquer: simpler, straightforward frameworks to use as a start
[4] Decode and conquer: simpler, straightforward frameworks to use as a start
[5] Stratechery blog: great blog on tech trends and strategy.
[6] What's the company's goals?
[7] What's the market opportunity?
[8] What's the success metrics?
[9] Data structures (Arrays, Linked List, Trees, Graphs, Hash table, Stacks, Queues).
[10] Database designs: pros and cons.
[11] Web vulnerabilities (XSS, SQL injection)
[12] [Product Design] Steps to designing product features
[13] User segmentation / persona
[14] Customer research methodology (UXR)
[15] [Analytical] Metrics and Data collection
[16] [Analytical] Metrics dips and spikes - how to analyze issues and trends
[17] Framework to review & finalize: [Strategy] Tradeoff, new market entry, CEO-level issues and strategy, pricing
[18] I suggest you build up your own framework this way too: start with simplified frameworks / frameworks you read from books, then modify and add more notes as you practice.
[19] Clarify: market, timing, constraints
[20] Assume goals & why does it matter for Google
[21] [Optional if product is vague] Value chain + Competitor: to decide where to play.
[22] Paying attention to user trends and current events is a plus
[23] Note: I suggest doing mock interviews with calibrated PMs (those who have done interviews before and know how to evaluate candidates).
[24] You can find a lot of sample PM questions (but not necessarily answers) from:
[25] In total I suggest practicing 70-100 questions on your own, 2-3 times each (in details), plus probably 50+ more from mock interviews.
[26] Be confident: being posed, confident, and calm during interviews helps a lot.
[27] Think about the users first, always: PMs have to be user-centric.
[28] Always evaluate: your ideas / calculation / strategy will always have loopholes.
[29] Have good moonshot ideas: you are also evaluated based on your creativity.
[30] Think of moonshots as something not obvious + a blend of new technology is a plus.

PM interviewers look for candidates who possess key skills and qualities such as knowledge of the industry, confidence, and the ability to think critically. To demonstrate knowledge, one can do mock interviews with calibrated PMs or practice with peer-interviews. It is also important to be aware of potential drawbacks and loopholes in the industry. Confidence is key during interviews, and being posed and calm can help a lot. Technical knowledge is also important for PM positions that require it, and at least 3-5 technical mock interviews are recommended for Google PM interviews. One can find sample PM questions from various sources.

Sources:
[0] : understand and remember key knowledge required to perform well in a PM interview
[1] Note: I suggest doing mock interviews with calibrated PMs (those who have done interviews before and know how to evaluate candidates).
[2] A good PMs will always think about these drawbacks / loopholes without prompting from interviewers.
[3] Peer-interviews can be useful too so you can see different approaches people take; and they are often better when you are not confident yet to practice with PMs.
[4] Be confident: being posed, confident, and calm during interviews helps a lot.
[5] You can find a lot of sample PM questions (but not necessarily answers) from:
[6] At least 3-5 technical mock interviews if you are interviewing for PM positions that require technical knowledge

According to the sources, some key skills and qualities that PM interviewers look for in candidates include analytical frameworks for metrics and estimations [1], the ability to clarify market, timing, and constraints [2], solution brainstorming and ranking [3], the ability to summarize and give an elevator pitch [4], creativity and moonshot ideas [5] [6], user-centric thinking [7], the ability to evaluate different strategies and suggest both short and long-term strategies [8], the ability to explain data schema and general architecture choices [9], the ability to brainstorm user segmentation and needs [10]-[11], and confidence and calmness during the interview [12]. To demonstrate these skills and qualities during the interview, one can prepare their own frameworks and notes [13], practice answering questions in detail [14], do lots of mock interviews and refine frameworks after each practice [15], think about the big picture and discuss how an idea is good for the company and users [16], and be better at handling multiple types of questions, not just memorizing solutions [17]. Additionally, it is important to think about the users first and always evaluate ideas and strategies for loopholes and drawbacks [18] [19].

Sources:
[1] Analytical frameworks: metrics & estimations
[2] Clarify: market, timing, constraints
[3] Solution brainstorming + rank
[4] Summary & Elevator pitch: Be good at storytelling here!
[5] Have good moonshot ideas: you are also evaluated based on your creativity.
[6] Have good moonshot ideas: you are also evaluated based on your creativity.
[7] Think about the users first, always: PMs have to be user-centric.
[8] Evaluate different strategy: what’s the tradeoff
[9] Explain data schema, general architecture choice, and big blocks (clients, app servers, database, and how they talk to each other)
[10] [i] Brainstorm user segmentation: having meaningful user segments is not easy.
[11] Then for each segment, brainstorm unique pain points.
[12] Be confident: being posed, confident, and calm during interviews helps a lot.
[13] I suggest you go through the materials listed and prepare your own frameworks / notes.
[14] Each day, practice 3-4 questions and write down answers in detail.
[15] : do lots of mock interviews, refine framework after each practice
[16] So when doing tradeoffs between ideas / options, always discuss the general strategy and how an idea is good for the company & the users.
[17] So please practice to be better at handling multiple types of questions, NOT to memorize solutions)
[18] Always evaluate: your ideas / calculation / strategy will always have loopholes.
[19] A good PMs will always think about these drawbacks / loopholes without prompting from interviewers.

Approaching strategy-type questions in a PM interview can be challenging as there is no one-size-fits-all framework. However, it is important to understand and remember key knowledge required to perform well in a PM interview. One can find a lot of sample PM questions from various sources, including "Cracking the PM Interview" and online resources. A good PM should always think about the drawbacks and loopholes without prompting from interviewers. It is suggested to practice 1-2 questions per day and schedule mock interviews with calibrated PMs who have done interviews before and know how to evaluate candidates. Peer-interviews can also be useful to see different approaches people take. By practicing extensively, one can expect that most questions in the actual interview will be somewhat similar to other questions they have practiced before, although PM interviewers are known to be creative and may surprise candidates with new types of questions.

Sources:
[0] STRATEGY -It’s hard to have one framework for strategy type of questions.
[1] : understand and remember key knowledge required to perform well in a PM interview
[2] Cracking the PM interview - reference only.
[3] A good PMs will always think about these drawbacks / loopholes without prompting from interviewers.
[4] Note: I suggest doing mock interviews with calibrated PMs (those who have done interviews before and know how to evaluate candidates).
[5] Peer-interviews can be useful too so you can see different approaches people take; and they are often better when you are not confident yet to practice with PMs.

Approaching strategy-type questions in a PM interview requires a structured approach. One should clarify the market, timing, and constraints [1], assume goals and consider why they matter for the company [2], and potentially clarify the technology, size, cost, and limitations [3]. It may also be helpful to consider the value chain and competitors to decide where to play [4]. Once the product is defined, one should target users and choose one [5], consider the user journey and pain points [6], and potentially determine a pricing model [7]. For strategy questions, it may be helpful to make short-term and long-term recommendations [8] and to craft a compelling elevator pitch [9]. One framework for reviewing and finalizing product design is CIRCLES, which can be modified as needed [10]. It is also important to evaluate different strategies and consider tradeoffs [11], and to have good moonshot ideas that demonstrate creativity [12]. Finally, it is important to clarify any vague words in the prompt and keep a separate list of assumptions for easy tracking [13] [14].

Sources:
[1] Clarify: market, timing, constraints
[2] Assume goals & why does it matter for Google
[3] [Optional if technology is given] Clarify technology: Size, cost, who can use it, limitation (pros & cons)
[4] [Optional if product is vague] Value chain + Competitor: to decide where to play.
[5] Target users & choose one.
[6] User Journey & painpoints + rank
[7] [Optional if monetization question] Pricing model: fremium, bundling, pay-as-you-go, subscription, razor and blades, tier-
[8] [Optional if strategy question] Strategy recommendation: for what to build in short vs. long-term
[9] Summary & Elevator pitch: Be good at storytelling here!
[10] Framework to review & finalize: Product design (based on CIRCLES but modified as I practice)
[11] Evaluate different strategy: what’s the tradeoff
[12] Have good moonshot ideas: you are also evaluated based on your creativity.
[13] Clarify each vague word of the prompt
[14] Tips: keep a separate list of assumptions for easy tracking

qaTask.question: How can one approach strategy-type questions in a PM interview, and what are some common frameworks or techniques for addressing them?
qaTask.answer:
Approaching strategy-type questions in a PM interview can be challenging as there is no one-size-fits-all framework. However, it is important to understand and remember key knowledge required to perform well in a PM interview. One can find a lot of sample PM questions from various sources, including "Cracking the PM Interview" and online resources. A good PM should always think about the drawbacks and loopholes without prompting from interviewers. It is suggested to practice 1-2 questions per day and schedule mock interviews with calibrated PMs who have done interviews before and know how to evaluate candidates. Peer-interviews can also be useful to see different approaches people take. By practicing extensively, one can expect that most questions in the actual interview will be somewhat similar to other questions they have practiced before, although PM interviewers are known to be creative and may surprise candidates with new types of questions.

[5] Peer-interviews can be useful too so you can see different approaches people take; and they are often better when you are not confident yet to practice with PMs.

qaTask.question: How can one approach strategy-type questions in a PM interview, and what are some common frameworks or techniques for addressing them?
qaTask.answer:
Approaching strategy-type questions in a PM interview requires a structured approach. One should clarify the market, timing, and constraints [1], assume goals and consider why they matter for the company [2], and potentially clarify the technology, size, cost, and limitations [3]. It may also be helpful to consider the value chain and competitors to decide where to play [4]. Once the product is defined, one should target users and choose one [5], consider the user journey and pain points [6], and potentially determine a pricing model [7]. For strategy questions, it may be helpful to make short-term and long-term recommendations [8] and to craft a compelling elevator pitch [9]. One framework for reviewing and finalizing product design is CIRCLES, which can be modified as needed [10]. It is also important to evaluate different strategies and consider tradeoffs [11], and to have good moonshot ideas that demonstrate creativity [12]. Finally, it is important to clarify any vague words in the prompt and keep a separate list of assumptions for easy tracking [13] [14].
